Entering Service 
The train may not enter service from a Maintenance Depot if the Driver feels that the damage to the cab side 
window is sufficient that they would struggle to see train dispatch equipment through the window. 

When in Service 
No speed restriction. 

Consideration should be given to boxing in the cab or turning the train wherever possible so that the cab will not 
require to be used.  

If the Driving Cab is required to be used by the Driver, it is at the Driver’s discretion to allow the train to remain in 
service.  

If the window is obscured, the judgment of the Driver and Guard should be sought as to whether the unit is fit to 
remain in traffic.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
Driver and Maintenance Controller to complete a risk assessment questionnaire per ARB 12. “Procedure Following 
Report of Unsatisfactory Brake Performance”. 

Driver and Maintenance Controller to decide on whether it is safe for the train to remain in service and whether any 
restrictions should apply.  

Maintenance Controller and Duty Service Delivery Manager to discuss the outcome of conversations with the 
Driver. If it has been decided that the level of braking available is categorised as “Unsafe Braking Performance” the 
train shall be detrained at the First Suitable Station and then taken out of service at the Next Available Location.   

In all circumstances, the train must end the day at a location that is capable of conducting a brake test in 
accordance with that vehicle’s maintenance schedule (VMI). 

When the service is formed of more than a single unit, the OTMR download must cover all units involved. 

The Maintenance Controller and Duty Service Delivery Manager are advise that next steps and responsibilities are 
provided in the GWR Appendix to the rule module 12 (Pages 73 & 74) and this document should be read in 
conjunction with this DOTE table.

General Incident 

Note – Class 15x and Class 16x fleets are going through a modification phase.  Some units are fitted with bar couplers, others retain 
conventional BSI couplers at the inner end.  Check with Maintenance Control before acting.  

Option 1 – Preferred Choice 
Box in the defective vehicle with another multiple unit of a compatible type.  Providing that through brake control is available between units train 
may proceed. If there are 4 vehicles with working brakes to every un-braked vehicle on the train it may remain in service until the end of the day 
although speed must be restricted to 10mph below line speed where the line speed is greater than 35mph.  

If there are less than 4 vehicles with working brakes to every un-braked vehicle, the train shall proceed at a reduced speed to the First Suitable 
Station where passengers shall be detrained. The train can then continue in non-passenger service to the Next Available Location.   The speed 
restriction will depend on the Driver’s opinion based on the consideration of available brake force, weather conditions, and gradients.  

Option 2 – 2nd Choice 
If it is not possible to box in the defective vehicle, the train may proceed in Passenger Service to the First Suitable Station providing that the 
defective vehicle has a working parking brake and a competent person supplied to apply it in an emergency. The train can then continue in non-
passenger service to the Next Available Location.   A speed restriction of 5mph applies to all moves in this condition. 

Option 3 – 3rd choice 
If both the brakes and the parking brake are isolated it may still be possible to move the train providing the gradient profile of the line means that 
were the defective vehicle to break away from the formation it would not roll away and the speed is restricted to 5mph. 

• 
• 

For trains with no brakes on the first vehicle, this means the train may only proceed if the gradient is rising in the direction of travel.  
For trains with no brakes on the rear vehicle, the train may only proceed if the gradient is level or falling in the direction of travel. 

If option 3 is used, or an alternative method of working is required, speak to 2nd Line Operations On-Call first. 

GERT8000 (Rule Book) Modules

Option 1 – 1st Choice

brakes to every un-braked vehicle (excluding locomotives on loco hauled trains), on the train it may remain in service until the end of the day 
although speed must be restricted to 10mph below line speed where the line speed is greater than 35mph.   

Class 255 restricted to 20mph if assisted in rear by a train, or 40mph if a locomotive is used.  

If there are less than 4 vehicles with working brakes to every un-braked vehicle (excluding locomotives on loco hauled trains), the train shall 
proceed at a reduced speed to the First Suitable Station where passengers shall be detrained. The train can then continue in non-passenger 
service to the Next Available Location.   The speed restriction will depend on the Driver’s opinion based on the consideration of available brake 
force, weather conditions, and gradients. Controllers to note this applies to a Class 255. 

Option 2 – 2nd Choice 
If it is not possible to box in the defective vehicle, the train may proceed in Passenger Service to the First Suitable Station providing that the 
defective vehicle has a working parking brake and a competent person supplied to apply it in an emergency. The train can then continue in non-
passenger service to the Next Available Location.   A speed restriction of 5mph applies to all moves in this condition. 

Option 3 – 3rd choice 
If both the brakes and the parking brake are isolated it may still be possible to move the train providing the gradient profile of the line means that 
were the defective vehicle to break away from the formation it would not roll away and the speed is restricted to 5mph.

2+3 Formation

brake force, weather conditions, and gradients. 2+3 Formation must not exceed 75mph. 

For Example - there are multiple isolations i.e. two coaches or one power car bogie and one coach. The 
above must be applied.

If the E70 or DW2 Brake Control Unit is isolated, the train can only be driven from the opposite end.  

For example, if the Brake Control Unit is isolated on the front power car, the train can only be driven from the 
rear power car.   

It may be possible for the train to continue forward if the defective or isolated brake control unit is at the opposite 
end to the cab which is required to be leading.  Controllers are to note.  In this scenario there is no speed 
restriction for a Class 255 as the maximum operating speed of the Class 255 traction is not permitted above 
100mph. 

Upon arrival at the destination, unless the set can be turned to keep the defective vehicle on the rear of the 
formation, the train will need assistance to a Maintenance Depot for repair. 

If the train is required to proceed in a direction which means that the power car with the defective Brake Controller is 
leading, the train will need to be driven from the trailing power car (a propelling move).  Follow the process defined 
in table 79 “Failure of Driving Cab Controls”.    

Note that if propelling with an isolated Brake Control Unit, only the emergency brake position will be available in the 
cab at the defective end.   

In the unlikely event of a brake test being required then the single man test will not work and a second person will 
be required to ensure continuity from the rear power car. 

GERT8000 (Rule Book) Modules

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

Where a through gangway exists, passengers should be transferred to the front portion of the train. Following this, 
the gangway doors either side of the break-in continuity are to be closed and locked shut.   

Before movement commences, a competent person must be placed in the front cab of the rear portion.  The duties 
of this person will be to: 

• 

release the brakes on the rearmost portion when the movement commences;   

•  apply the brakes to stop the train in an emergency if it divides; and  

• 

carry out emergency protection of the train if it has become divided. 

The maximum speed of any movement is 5mph. 

During the movement, the braking systems of the two halves of the train will work – albeit independently of each 
other. For instance, if the brakes are applied from the front; only the front portion will brake. The Driver should be 
reminded of this and control the train accordingly.   

If cab-to-cab communications are required to control the move, note that cab-to-cab intercom and buzzer will not 
function.  Instead, train crew should use the Driver Multi Party call functionality provided by GSM-R to provide a 
voice link between cabs.  

230001 
Note that 230001 is a 3-car formation with fixed bar couplers between the cars so from a brake continuity 
perspective they are effectively ‘hard wired’. Although the cab ends of the unit are equipped with ex-London 
Underground ‘Wedgelock’ couplers, they have no electrical connections, and there is nothing else on the network 
that 230001 can routinely couple to without use of the emergency coupler (refer to document FCBTT-00005 for a 
full description of how to rescue / recover 230001). 

GERT8000 (Rule Book) Modules

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
Trains must not be allowed to enter service with faulty heating or cooling in a cab that is required to be used if it is 
anticipated that the temperature within the cab is likely to affect the safe operation of the train during the journey. 

If the train is already in service, you must consult with the Driver of the train and consider action to mitigate the effects 
of the fault equipment.  Such mitigation may include: 

•  boxing the cab in; or 
• 
• 

the provision of hot or cold drinks; or  
running at reduced speed with a door/window opened  

If doors or windows need to be opened, speed should be restricted such that any cab safety systems can still be 
heard above any wind noise.  The Driver should determine the extent of speed restriction required.   

If it is not possible to successfully mitigate against the effects of the cab temperature the train must be taken out of 
service at the Next Available Location or sooner if the Driver feels that conditions are intolerable. 

A  Driver  may  refuse  to  work  under  the  grounds  of  Health  and  Safety  if  the  cab  temperature  exceeds  26  degrees 
Celsius.   If this is the case, a fitter or Crew Manager shall be asked to inspect the cab to check the cab temperature.

Vermin Infestation 
Food and drink must not be served if vermin have been sighted in the buffet vehicle (this includes the seated area of 
the vehicle).   

Disposal of buffet stock to be agreed with Catering on-call.    

The vehicle shall be returned to the depot at the first convenient opportunity (without causing cancellation) for vermin 
removal.  The vermin must be removed, and the vehicle must be cleaned before the vehicle re-entering service.  

Note that not all depots can carry out the required level of cleaning following an incident such as this - consult IMS1160 
section 11 for details of which depots can undertake this work.  

Water Contamination 
Upon receiving notification of suspected water contamination of a catering vehicle, arrangements shall be made to 
have  the  water  supply  tanks  re-chlorinated  at  the  earliest  available  opportunity.  The  Catering  On-Call  shall  be 
contacted to establish whether any restrictions need to apply to food service activities until the chlorination has taken 
place.  

Contaminated Food 
If a report or allegation of contaminated food is received, the Duty Service Delivery Manager shall contact the Catering 
On-Call.  If it is believed that there may be contaminated buffet equipment (refrigerators etc) the Duty Service Delivery 
Manager shall agree on a suitable course of action with the Catering On-Call and the Maintenance Controller.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

The Maintenance Controller must refer to the CDL / SDO fault-finding flowcharts (Contained in the SDO manual) to 
try and rectify the fault in the first instance.  

If the fault cannot be rectified: 

•  Doors must not be budget locked shut. When the CDL is defective or isolated, the drop light window 

locking mechanism will no longer secure the window and the system must be treated as defective.  
Controllers must refer to Table 19 in conjunction with this table. 

•  Passengers must be advised via PA and/or patrolling of the vehicle to keep away from the door areas of 

defective vehicles.  

•  Consider placing members of staff near vestibule areas to keep customers away from the doors and monitor 

“at-risk” groups of passengers.  

•  The train must be detrained at the First Suitable Station.  

No restriction of speed is required whilst this movement is taking place. 

Once passengers have been  detrained at the First Suitable Station, all doors on the train must be budget locked.  
Following this, the train may proceed ECS to a Maintenance Depot.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

If the division has occurred between vehicles between which there was not a through gangway or if the train was not in passenger  use,  RAIB 
consent is not required before movement or recoupling takes place and they need not be informed out-of-hours (Schedule 2 notification). 

The train must not be moved or re-coupled unless authority is also given by the Engineering On-Call Manager and the Controlling Signaller. 

Broken Screw Coupling between Locomotive and Train 
An emergency screw coupling shall be used to recouple the locomotive to the train.  The defective coupling must be retained for metallurgical 
testing.   

Once recoupled, the train may run normally and does not need to be taken out of service.   

Broken buckeye coupling between Mkiii trailer cars of a Class 255 set or between the power car and Mkiii trailer var. 
Buckeye couplers must be examined and must not to be re-coupled without a Rolling Stock Technician being present.  Once the two halves of 
the train have been recoupled passengers must be prevented from using the gangway between vehicles at which the division occurred.  A 
member of staff or emergency barrier should be used for this purpose.  

Passengers must be de-trained at the First Suitable Station, following which the train may proceed ECS as far as the Next Available Location.  

Broken buckeye coupling between carriages of a Loco-Hauled train.  
Vehicles must be re-coupled using the emergency screw coupling.  
Once the two halves of the train have been recoupled passengers must be prevented from using the gangway between vehicles at which the 
division occurred.  A member of staff or emergency barrier should be used for this purpose.  

Passengers must be de-trained at the First Suitable Station, following which the train may proceed ECS as far as the Next Available Location.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
If the division has occurred between vehicles in passenger service and there was potential that somebody could have 
(or  has)  fallen  from  the  train,  the  Duty  Service  Delivery  Manager  must  promptly  inform  the  RAIB  (Schedule  1 
notification).  Re-coupling and/or further movement of the train must not be attempted without RAIB authorisation. 

If the division occurred between vehicles between which there was not a through gangway or if the train was not in 
passenger  use,  RAIB  consent  is  not  required  before  movement  or  recoupling  takes  place  and  they  need  not  be 
informed out-of-hours (Schedule 2 notification).  

The train must not be moved or re-coupled unless authority is also given by the Engineering On-Call Manager and 
the Controlling Signaller. 

Before  any  decision  is  made  to  re-couple  the  Duty  Service  Delivery  Manager  and  Maintenance  Controller  should 
establish whether re-coupling is a suitable course of action or whether alternative arrangements such as a controlled 
evacuation of passengers should be undertaken instead.  

If the break has occurred within a fixed bar coupler, it may not be possible to recouple the vehicles on site. Class 387 
& Class 80x vehicles have a fixed bar coupler within the unit itself whilst some representatives of Classes Class 150/2, 
Class 158, and Class 16x maybe bar coupler fitted between vehicles depending on the status of the fleet upgrade 
programme.  

The train must not be moved or re-coupled unless this has authorised by the Engineering On-Call Manager and the 
Controlling Signaller.  

If the decision is taken to re-couple the vehicles, corridor connections between vehicles (where provided) must be 
locked out of use.  

Where several units are coupled in multiple, only those units between or within which the division has occurred need 
be treated as defective.  Other units may be detached from the formation and can remain in service.

End Doors and Emergency Egress 
On this traction type, door letters E and F are determined as End Doors.  
All passenger doors are fitted with emergency egress handles.  

Instructions 
A vehicle or vehicles with one or more doors locked out of use must be placed out of passenger use at or before the Next Station when either:  

• an End Door has been locked out of use; or  
• a door has been locked out of use adjacent to a gangway connection that cannot be made; or  
• two adjacent doors on the same side of the train  

If a door is locked out of use that provides access to the allocated wheelchair accommodation when in service.  The train is permitted to remain in 
service until the end of the day but must finish the day at a Maintenance Depot.  The wheelchair accommodation must not be used.  The Customer 
Experience Manager must be informed promptly for ensuring this information is communicated to the relevant functions and advertised accordingly.  
Reference IMS 1650-117 

Driver Access and Egress 
Door letters E and F are required for Driver access and egress to the vehicle if the driving cab in this vehicle is required to be used.  

The cab in this vehicle can still be used even if doors E and/or F are locked out of use providing that the door(s) can be unlocked and opened to 
facilitate access to the line side if required.  

Checking isolated doors 
When carrying out a door isolation check to ensure that it can’t be opened manually by pushing or pulling it.

Slam Door Test 
A slam door test can be performed on a door which is suspected to be defective either following a reported fault with the door or 
an unobserved door on the catch.  The purpose of this test is to establish the correct function of the door such as to establish a 
degree of certainty as to whether there is a genuine fault with the door. 

A slam door test will normally only be performed at a location where the door can be tested from a station platform without causing 
delay to the train.  If however the locking of a door out of use would subsequently require the evacuation of a vehicle, it is permissible 
to delay a train at the first station at which the door can be platformed in under to undertake the test.

Doors can be isolated using a carriage key in the overhead panel. This method will place the doors out of use but will allow 
passengers to open them in an emergency via the door egress if required. Therefore, there are no restrictions on isolating 
bodyside ‘end’ doors.  

A train with one or more doors isolated must finish at a Maintenance Depot at the end of day.  

Controllers must note that bi-parting gangway doors and internal saloon sliding doors being defective or isolated may cause the 
need to lock a vehicle out of use.  Controllers must follow the guidance in Table 61 for further guidance. 

If a door is isolated out of use that provides access to the allocated wheelchair accommodation when in service.  The train is permitted to remain 
in service until end of day but must finish the day at a Maintenance Depot.  The wheelchair accommodation must not be used.   The Customer 
Experience Manager must be informed promptly for ensuring this information is communicated to the relevant functions and advertised accordingly.   

Driver Access and Egress   

Both the Driver’s and Second man’s side cab doors are required for access and egress to the vehicle if the driving cab in this 
vehicle is required to be used. The cab in this vehicle can still be used even if the cab doors are locked out of use providing that 
the door(s) can be unlocked and opened to facilitate access to the line side if required

Doors Locked out of use or Isolated 
Doors can be isolated either electrically or mechanically. Electrical isolation involves isolating the door using the in-cab MiTRAC unit.  This method 
will place the doors out of use but will allow passengers to open them in an emergency via the door egress if required.   For more serious failures, 
the doors may require to be isolated using a carriage key in the Out of Service Lock above the affected doors.  If the doors  are mechanically 
isolated in this manner, the emergency egress facility will not work at the affected doors. 

Isolation of End Doors 
For the purposes of this instruction, the End Doors are identified as doors G and B of the DMOS vehicles at the extreme end of a formation.   

• 
• 

If the End Doors have been isolated electronically, the vehicle may remain in use and operate without restriction.  
If the End Doors have been isolated mechanically, and the affected vehicle is at the extreme leading or trailing end of the formation the 
vehicle must be placed out of passenger use no later than the First Suitable Station.  

Isolation of Multiple Doors 
If the Doors have been isolated electronically, the vehicle may remain in use and operate without restriction. 
A vehicle or vehicles with more than one door locked out of use mechanically must be placed out of passenger use at or before the Next Station 
when either: 
• 
• 

a door has been locked out of use adjacent to a gangway connection that cannot be made; or  
two adjacent doors on the same side of the train 

If a door is locked out of use that provides access to the allocated wheelchair accommodation when in service.  The train is permitted to remain in 
service  until  end  of  day  but  must  finish the  day  at  a  Maintenance Depot.    The  wheelchair  accommodation  must  not  be  used.    The  Customer 
Experience Manager must be informed promptly for ensuring this information is communicated to the relevant functions and advertised accordingly.   

If the Out of Service Lock cannot be fully turned or the Carriage Key will not disengage with the lock: 
In the event that the Out of Service Lock cannot be turned the full 90 degrees or if the carriage key cannot be removed from the lock, the door Out 
of Service lock has not been engaged correctly.  The Class 387 Traction Manual details the correct procedure to follow in this instance.   
If the Out of Service Lock has not been successfully engaged after five attempts, no further attempts must be made.  The vehicle must be placed 
out of passenger use at or before the Next Station.  

Driver Access and Egress 
Both the Driver’s and Second man’s side cab doors are required for access and egress to the vehicle if the driving cab in this vehicle is required to 
be used.  The cab in this vehicle can still be used even if the cab doors are locked out of use providing that the door(s) can be unlocked and opened 
to facilitate access to the line side if required

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
The operational response to a Door Open in Traffic incident is now defined in IMS1650-51 Door Open in Traffic. This 
process includes the actions to take for chain of care, evidence gathering and interview (and potentially) for-cause 
screening of colleagues implicated in the incident.    

There may also be a requirement to promptly advise the RAIB of a Door Open in Traffic incident and guidance for this 
is also set out on IMS1650-51. 

Following a door open in traffic which has been caused (or is suspected to have been caused) by a mechanical fault 
or defect the affected door(s) must be closed and treated as defective.  See “Doors – Defective or Isolated” for traction 
specific guidance.    

Once secured, the train will normally only be  allowed  to proceed as far as the First Suitable Station in passenger 
service before running no further than the Next Available Location for repair.  There are exceptions to this guidance, 
and IMS1650-51 must be referenced before any decision is taken to remove the train from service.

No action required if one door defective although the passenger ambience will be impacted by additional noise and draught.  
If two adjoining doors are locked open no immediate action is required but arrangements should be made to return the unit to a Maintenance Depot 
at the earliest opportunity for repairs to be carried out.

If both portions of the train are to remain in passenger service, the Controller must check to establish whether any external passenger doors are 
defective and have been isolated on either side of the doors which are locked closed.  

The passenger egress doors closest to the internal doors which are locked closed must be treated as “End Doors”. Consequently, if these doors 
are locked out of use; it may be that the vehicle needs to be placed out of passenger use at or before the Next Station.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

A train is permitted to enter non-passenger service from other than a maintenance depot with a defective or isolated DSD in a cab which requires 
to be used providing that:  

• 
• 
• 

the purpose of the journey is to move the train to a Maintenance Depot for repair;  
the speed of the journey is restricted in accordance with the Speed Restrictions table below; and 
if AWS/TPWS are defective or isolated, a Competent Person has been provided.  

Failure in Service  
If AWS/TPWS are also defective or isolated, the train MUST NOT be driven from the defective cab until a Competent Person has been 
provided. The Competent Person needs only to meet the requirement of IMS-1640-50 for DSD/DVD isolation and may therefore be the 
Guard or any other member of staff who meets the requirements of IMS1640-00. 

Following the isolation of the DSD equipment the speed at which a train may proceed is defined in the “Speed Restrictions” table below. The 
applicable speed restriction will depend upon the availability of a competent person and the functionality of the AWS/TPWS equipment in the 
affected cab.  

The train may only proceed in passenger service as far as the First Suitable Station where passengers must be detrained whether or not a 
Competent Person has been provided. After detraining passengers at the First Suitable Station the train may proceed ECS as far as the Next 
Available Location.  

Consideration should be given to turning the train or (in the case of multiple unit stock) boxing in the defective cab at or before the First Suitable 
Station to allow the train to remain in passenger service.  

Class 150/2 units 150202 150207 and 150216  
The above units do not have a DSD isolation facility. If the DSD becomes defective on these vehicles the EBS will have to be operated in order 
to allow the train to be driven from the defective cab. (Refer to table 72 in addition to this table).

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

A train is permitted to enter non-passenger service from other than a maintenance depot with a defective or isolated DVD in a cab which requires 
to be used providing that:  

• 
• 
• 

the purpose of the journey is to move the train to a Maintenance Depot for repair;  
the speed of the journey is restricted in accordance with the Speed Restrictions table below; and  
if AWS/TPWS are defective or isolated, a Competent Person has been provided.  

Failure in Service  
If AWS/TPWS are also defective or isolated, the train MUST NOT be driven from the defective cab until a Competent Person has been 
provided. The Competent Person needs only to meet the requirement of IMS-1640-50 for DSD/DVD isolation and may therefore be the 
Guard or any other member of staff who meets the requirements of IMS1640-00.  

Following the isolation of the DVD equipment the speed at which a train may proceed is defined in the “Speed Restrictions” table below. The 
applicable speed restriction will depend upon the availability of a competent person and the functionality of the AWS/TPWS equipment in the 
affected cab.  

The train may only proceed in passenger service as far as the First Suitable Station where passengers must be detrained whether or not a 
Competent Person has been provided. After detraining passengers at the First Suitable Station the train may proceed ECS as far as the Next 
Available Location.  

Consideration should be given to turning the train or (in the case of multiple unit stock) boxing in the defective cab at or before the First Suitable 
Station to allow the train to remain in passenger service.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

Entering Service from other than a Maintenance Depot 
A Class 255 or Class 80x is permitted to enter non-passenger service from other than a maintenance depot with a defective or isolated DVD in a 
cab which requires to be used providing that: 
• 
• 
• 

the purpose of the journey is to move the train to a Maintenance Depot for repair; 
the speed of the journey is restricted in accordance with the Speed Restrictions table below; and 
if AWS/TPWS are defective or isolated, a Competent Person has been provided. 

Class 255 or Class 80x Operating over ATP fitted lines.  
In the event of a DVD equipment failure or isolation, a Class 255 or Class 80x may enter and remain passenger service without restriction providing 
that: 

• 
• 
• 
• 

The train is fitted with ATP and that the system is functioning correctly; and 
The defective cab will only be driven from whilst the train is operating over lines fitted with ATP; and 
A Competent Person is provided at the earliest possible opportunity (no later than the Next Available Location); and 
Network Rail have been informed and have agreed to ensure that the train remains on ATP fitted lines throughout the journey.  

Class 255 or Class 80x NOT Operating Over ATP fitted lines or with defective ATP 
If AWS/TPWS are also defective or isolated, the train MUST NOT be driven from the defective cab until a Competent Person has been provided. 
The Competent Person needs only to meet the requirement of IMS-1640-50 for DSD/DVD isolation and may therefore be the Guard or any other 
member of staff who meets the requirements of IMS1640-00.  
Following the isolation of the DVD equipment the speed at which a train may proceed is defined in the “Speed Restrictions” table below. The 
applicable speed restriction will depend upon the availability of a competent person and the functionality of the AWS/TPWS equipment in the 
affected cab.  
On Class 80x traction, if the DVD equipment is isolated, the Driver MUST ensure that they keep the DSD pedal depressed. Any release of the 
DSD pedal will result in an immediate emergency brake application.  
The train may only proceed in passenger service as far as the First Suitable Station where passengers must be detrained whether or not a 
Competent Person has been provided. After detraining passengers at the First Suitable Station the train may proceed ECS as far as the Next 
Available Location. Consideration should be given to turning the train or (in the case of multiple unit stock) boxing in the defective cab at or 
before the First Suitable Station to allow the train to remain in passenger service.

If the DSD system is isolated on a Class 80x, the DVD system must also be isolated.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

EBS operated on single multiple unit (Not 58 hybrid 3-car units): 
The train may proceed in passenger service as far as the First Suitable Station where the passengers must be removed from the train.  Following 
this action, the train may proceed ECS to a Maintenance Depot.  

EBS operated on a train formed of more than one multiple unit or a train formed of 158 hybrid 3-car units. 

If it is necessary to run units with the EBS operated in multiple:  
•  Where possible, passengers to be accommodated within the leading unit only.   
Through gangway connections between units should be closed as a precaution.  
• 
A Competent Person should be provided where possible – this will normally be the Guard if one is present.  Where provided, the 
• 
Competent Person must ride in the rear unit.  

The extent of movement that is possible following the operation of the EBS will depend upon the availability of a Competent Person and the 
ability to transfer customers to the leading unit.   

If a Competent Person is available on a train formed of more than one multiple unit or 158 hybrid 3-car units: 

The train may proceed normally to the First Suitable Station, where the passengers must be de-trained. Following this, the train may proceed 
ECS to a Maintenance Depot. 

If no Competent Person is available on a train formed of more than one multiple unit or 158 hybrid 3-car units: 

The train may proceed normally to the First Suitable Station, whereupon passengers must be de-trained. Disposal of the train will then depend 
upon the network infrastructure over which the train would be required to operate to clear the line.  

Where the line is operated under Track Circuit Block regulations (e.g., all lines fitted with track circuits / axle counters for the purposes 
of train detection).   The train may continue ECS to the Next Available Location (and any associated depot/siding) without waiting for the 
provision of a Competent Person.  

Where the line is not operated under Track Circuit Block regulations (e.g., Absolute Block). A Competent Person must be provided 
before the train may depart ECS form the Next Available Location.  Once a Competent Person has been provided, the train may continue 
ECS to the Next Available Location (and any associated depot/siding). 

Proceeding Without a Competent Person with EBS operated on a train formed of more than one multiple unit or a Class 158 hybrid 3-car 
units  
The following additional risk control measures must be briefed to the Driver before movement commences: 

• 
• 

If the train is on track circuit block lines, at least one TCA must be working on the rear unit.  
If the train is on a single line the Driver must be instructed to stop at the exit to the single line and check that their train is complete before 
proceeding.   

Maintenance Controllers are to consult TEAMS instructions regarding door isolations where EBS and TIS are isolated at the same time.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

EBS operated on single multiple unit  
The train may proceed in passenger service as far as the First Suitable Station where the passengers must be removed from the train.  Following 
this action, the train may proceed ECS to a Maintenance Depot.  

EBS operated on a train formed of more than one multiple unit. 

The extent of movement that is possible following the operation of the EBS will depend upon the availability of a Competent Person or 
whether other safety systems have been isolated.    

If a Competent Person is available on a train formed of more than one multiple unit: 

The train may proceed normally to the First Suitable Station, where the passengers must be de-trained. Following this, the train may 
proceed ECS to a Maintenance Depot providing the Competent Person remains with the train. 

If no Competent Person is available on a train formed of more than one multiple unit: 
The train can be allowed to proceed normally to the First Suitable Station subject to the following movement conditions: 

• 
• 

Passengers should be accommodated in the leading unit only where possible.  
The PA system must not be isolated and the Driver must be advised to monitor the PA health/fault light during the journey and 
to bring the train to an immediate stand if the fault light becomes illuminated as it may mean that the train has become divided. 
If the PA system is defective and TIS is also isolated,  a Competent Person must  be provided at the Next Station before any 
further movement takes place. (Not applicable to Class 80x) 
If the train is on track circuit block lines, at least one TCA must be working on the rear unit.  

• 
If the train is on a single line the Driver must be instructed to stop at the exit to the single line and check that their train is complete 
before proceeding.   

• 

Upon arrival at the First Suitable Station; passengers must be detrained.  Disposal of the train from this station will then depend upon the network 
infrastructure over which the train would be required to operate to clear the line.  

Where the line is operated under Track Circuit Block regulations (e.g., all lines fitted with track circuits / axle counters for the 
purposes of train detection).   The train may continue ECS to the Next Available Location (and any associated depot/siding) without 
waiting for the provision of a Competent Person.  

Where the line is not operated under Track Circuit Block regulations (e.g., Absolute Block). A Competent Person must be 
provided before the train may depart ECS form the Next Available Location.  Once a Competent Person has been provided, the 
train may continue ECS to the Next Available Location (and any associated depot/siding). 

Class 175 
The EBS for a Class 175 is referred to as a ‘Brake Continuity Switch’. All above instructions apply. When the Brake Continuity Switch has been 
operated, the train must not be propelled. If assistance is required at the front of the train, the Brake Continuity Switch  must be operated in the 
leading cab of the assisting unit.  

Maintenance Controllers are to consult TEAMS instructions regarding door isolations where EBS & TIS are isolated

Bodyside Indicator Light fails to illuminate when expected 
The train may continue in service without restriction, but the issue should be logged as a defect in the Maintenance 
Management System, for further investigation. 

Bodyside Indicator Light Illuminated  
The train has bodyside indicator lights which can be either orange or white. There are several bodyside indicator 
lights throughout the length of the train.  

A steady orange bodyside indicator light means: 

•  That the door interlock circuit has been broken; this often means that a door is open; this would include cab 

doors. Could also mean that the Train Door Circuit Breaker (TDCB) has tripped. 

•  That the fire alarm has been activated; this could be activated either by saloon smoke alarms, or the 

traction battery fire detection system.  

A steady white bodyside indicator light* means: 

•  That there is a General Fault, which would also be indicated to the Driver in the cab by the General Fault 

light being illuminated.** 

•  That the passenger emergency alarm has been activated. 
•  That a door emergency egress device has been operated. Note that the white BIL will be illuminated whilst 
the door is still shut, but once the train speed reaches 2mph or less it will be possible to fully open the door, 
at which point an orange bodyside light will also illuminate. 

A flashing white bodyside indicator light means: 

•  That the unit is Fast Charging.  

*Note: it is possible that an illuminated steady white bodyside light may be observed while the train is in motion, which may be 
reported to the signaller by other railway staff (although there is no requirement to do so, unlike an orange bodyside light which 
must be reported in accordance with Rule Book module TW5 section 13). Signallers may disregard any such reports of a steady 
illuminated white bodyside light, as this is not an immediate cause for concern, unless the driver of 230001 reports it as such 
(e.g. if an egress has been operated, but a door is not yet open). 

**See Table 90 for more information on the General Fault light. 

Before any movement and subsequent journey commences, the Driver must alert the Controlling signaller to the 
fact that the train will be proceeding with an external BIL illuminated.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

In the event of a failure of Driving Cab Controls in the leading cab of a train, the preferred option is for the Driver to 
change ends and then drive the train in the opposite direction.  The train may then continue normally providing that 
suitable arrangements can be made for passengers who are unable to continue with their journey and that the 
defective cab is not required to be used again.  

For multiple-unit stock, boxing in the cab with another (compatible) multiple unit will also allow the train to continue 
normally.  Similarly, for locomotive hauled stock, where possible an assisting locomotive should be provided in order 
to either box in the defective cab or assist the train from the rear.  

If none of the above is possible, it will be necessary to arrange a propelling move in order to clear the line. 

Propelling movements must be arranged and implemented in accordance with the guidance provided in Control 
Manual Document IMS-1650-91 “Driving a train form other than the leading cab”.    

Providing the requirements of IMS-1650-91 can be met, there is no need for an on-call manager to specially 
authorise a propelling movement.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
The  PTSOL  fire  detection  system  covers  the  high  voltage  equipment  on  the  PTSOL  vehicle.  This  high  voltage 
equipment is only used if the train is operating off 25kv AC Overhead supply.  

The health of the fire detection system on the PTSOL vehicle can be monitored through the in-cab MITRAC display.   

In the event that the fire system activates:

be cut. The Driver will be able to coast the train to a location where an examination can be carried out.  

This Driver must examine all high voltage electrical equipment on the PTSOL vehicle for signs of fire or overheating.  

If  there  are  signs  of  fire  or  overheating  the  opinion  of  a  Rolling  Stock  Technician  must  be  sought  before  further 
movement is attempted.  

If there are no signs of fire or over-heating.  
The  Driver  can  use  the  “Fire  Detection  Override  Screen”  on  the  in-cab  MITRAC  display  to  temporarily  isolate  the

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

If the vehicle is required to form part of a train which will contain other sleeping car vehicles in passenger service, the 
sleeping car with a defective fire system must be: 
•  marshalled at the end of the train; and 
locked out of use to passengers; 
• 
regularly patrolled by a sleeping car attendant.  
• 

Where these conditions cannot be met, the vehicle must not be allowed to enter service.   

A sleeping car with a defective fire alarm system must never be allowed to enter passenger service.  

If a fault develops whilst In Service 
If the fire control panel indicates a fault, the on-train Stewards must revert to working their own two vehicles only. 
They must observe the length of their allocated vehicles every 5 minutes and patrol the full length of the vehicles 
every 15 minutes.    

If the Stewards are unable to comply with this requirement, the Sleeper vehicle(s) affected must be placed out of 
passenger use immediately, with passengers moved to unaffected vehicles.

Entering DOO (Passenger) Service 
A train / traction unit may not Enter DOO (Passenger) service with defective GSM-R radio in any cab which is required to be 
used. Additionally, transportable or portable radio equipment is not sufficient to allow the train to enter DOO (Passenger) service 
due to the lack of a DSD alarm and Public Address talk-through facility. 

When in DOO Passenger Service 
If the GSM-R radio equipment becomes defective in service, the train may proceed in DOO Passenger Service as far as the First 
Suitable Station.   

Upon arrival at the First Suitable Station, In order for the train to remain in Passenger Service either; 

a). The train must cease to run as Driver Only Operated with the provision of a Guard (refer to Table 86 or 
b). The train can be turned or the defective cab boxed in.  

If neither a). nor b) is possible passengers must be detrained. The train can then proceed ECS as far as the Next Available 
location or a Maintenance Depot for repair providing this distance does not exceed 75 miles. 

Mobile phones are not permitted as a contingency method of work.

From Other than Maintenance Depot 
A train / traction unit may enter service from other than a Maintenance Depot providing;

INSTRUCTIONS 

If  the  message  ‘Registration  failed’  is  displayed  after  trying  to  register  the  cab  radio,  the  Driver  should  check  the 
registration code was entered correctly by attempting to register the cab radio again. 

If the second attempt also fails, the Driver should contact the signaller via the GSM-R cab radio using the number 
stored in the address book.   During this communication the Driver shall check whether: 

•  The Signaller is aware of a particular problem that may be causing registration failures; and 
•  The Signaller’s Train Describer is set correctly for the train which is being registered.   

This communication also confirms that the radio is correctly connected to the network and calls can be made. 

Driver able to contact the Signaller via GSM-R Radio 
One further attempt can be made to register the GSM-R radio. This registration may be made using a wild card code 
,found in the sectional appendix, if necessary. If the use of the wild card also fails, this must be reported back to the 
Signaller by the Driver. The Wild card code is generally ‘995’ unless at the following locations: 

Location 
Greenford Bay Platform 
Penzance Platforms 2, 3 & 4 

Wildcard 
996 
067 

If, having followed the above process all registration attempts are unsuccessful, trains can enter and remain in service 
(including  DOO  Passenger  Operation)  unregistered  provided  the  display  is  showing  GSM-R  GB.  However,  in  this 
state of partial registration, the train cannot be contacted by a Signaller by train ID.  Instead the signaller will need to 
look up the train by power car number or unit ID.    

Driver unable to contact the Signaller via GSM-R Radio 
If the Driver cannot contact the signaller via the GSM-R radio, the equipment must be treated as being completely 
defective – refer to Table 85 if the train is operating under DOO Passenger conditions, or otherwise Table 86.

Flashing General Fault Light  
The  most  common  cause  of  a  flashing  General  Fault  Light  will  be  an  issue  with  the  battery  charging  system 
(“generator”).    The  Driver  should  attempt  to  reset  the  system  by  reinstating  any  tripped  MCBs  and  pressing  the 
General Fault reset button.    

If the General Fault Light continues to flash or the battery charge system is OK.  
If the General Fault light continues to flash and it is not thought that this is due to a fault with the battery charge 
system, it may be indicative of a serious fault affecting one of the following on-train systems: 

•  Parking brake stuck on; 
•  Transmission not changing direction; 
•  Brake drag;  
•  Low main-res air; or 
•  Track Circuit Actuator.  

The Driver and Maintenance Controller (with support from the Turbo Helpline if appropriate) shall commence fault 
finding in order to establish the cause of the fault.  

The outcome of this investigation and the guidance of the Maintenance Controller and/or Turbo Helpline will be used 
by the Duty Service Delivery Manager in determining whether and where the train must be removed from service 
and any operational restrictions which will apply.   Where on-train equipment e.g., brakes or Track Circuit Actuators 
are isolated in order to extinguish the General Fault Light, the appropriate table of this document must be complied 
with.

INSTRUCTIONS 
If the General Fault light is lit, it may be indicative of a serious fault affecting one of the following on-train systems: 

• 
• 
• 
• 
• 
• 
• 
• 
• 
• 

Low main reservoir air pressure low 
Brake reservoir pressure low 
TCA fault 
Loss of traction battery power 
Battery/traction fire detection system activated or faulty 
Traction fault 
Earth fault 
Fast charge fault 
WSP fault 
Dragging brake 

The Driver and Maintenance Controller, with support from the Fast Charge Battery Train Team (FCBTT) On-Call 
Engineer if appropriate, shall commence fault finding in order to establish the cause of the fault.  

There is a local Fault Indication Panel (FIP) in each cab, so if the General Fault light is lit, but none of the local fault 
lights is lit, then the fault is not on that vehicle. However, the trailer vehicle does not have a local FIP, so the only 
way to find out what the fault is, where neither driving cab FIP is showing any indication, is to contact Maintenance 
Control, who can potentially use the Remote Condition Monitoring (RCM) to assist with the fault-finding investigation. 

Note that a simple trip/reset of the train can often fix the issue if a Power Pack (traction battery) fault light comes up 
on the FIP (and often in other cases too).The train will take a little while to boot up so wait approximately 5 to 7 
minutes after boot up for any Power Pack fault lights to clear. 

The outcome of the fault-finding investigation and the guidance of the Maintenance Controller and/or FCBTT On-
Call Engineer will be used by the Duty Service Delivery Manager in determining whether and where the train must 
be removed from service and any operational restrictions which will apply.  

Where on-train equipment (for example, but not limited to Brakes or Track Circuit Actuators) are isolated in order to 
extinguish the General Fault Light, the appropriate table of this document must be complied with.

INSTRUCTIONS 

Entering Service from other than a Maintenance Depot 
A train may enter service from other than a Maintenance Depot providing that at least one headlight is working correctly on every vehicle that is 
required to be at the front or rear of a train.  

Partial Failure in Service 
If one headlight becomes defective on a train in service which is fitted with two headlights, the train may complete its journeys for the remainder of 
the day without restriction, provided that its final journey of the day ends at a Maintenance Depot.   

Similarly if one or both marker lights (where fitted) become defective the train may complete its journeys for the remainder of the day providing at 
least one headlight is correctly functioning.  

If the headlight(s) have failed but the marker lights continue to work, this must be treated as a total failure (see below).  

Total Failure in Service 
If a vehicle is fitted with only one headlight, and this becomes defective whilst in service, or if both or all headlights become defective on a train in 
service which is fitted with more than one headlight an alternative white light must be provided on the front of the train and the speed of the train 
reduced according to the intensity of the light provided.   

The  table  below  sets  out  the  permissible  speed  of  the  train  with  an  alternative  white  light  on  the  front  and  the  corresponding  out  of  service 
requirement.

INSTRUCTIONS 

The Driver should use a heat sensitive crayon (a “Templistik”) to confirm whether the axle(s) are excessively hot.  

If no heat sensitive crayon is available, the Driver should try and gauge axle temperature by holding the back of their 
hand adjacent to the axle end but must not under any circumstance touch the axle.  

First Hot Axle Box (HABD) Activation 

If axle(s) are confirmed as hot.  
Refer to Table 96– Hot Axle Box – Confirmed Hot Axle.  

If the axle(s) are not hot.  
Check all axles on both sides of the vehicle concerned and the vehicles either side of the vehicle concerned. 

Providing no hot axles are found following a first activation, the train may proceed at line speed.  Within the 
next 50 miles the train must either pass over another Hot Axle Box Detector or the axle(s) in question be re-
examined by the Driver or a Rolling Stock Technician.  

Second HABD activation 
If this is the second or subsequent HABD activation for the same axle/side of the train the vehicle must be: 

•  Treated as a suspect hot axle if no fault is found following examination after the second HABD activation 

(refer to Table 97). 

•  Treated as defective if the axle is found hot following examination after the second HABD activation (refer to 

Table 96).

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

Clearing the Line 
Movement to clear the line must only take place once authorised by the Controlling Signaller and Driver. If following examination of the train the 
Driver has any doubts about the fitness of the train to be moved, the train must be examined by a Rolling Stock Technician before movement 
may commence.  

Movement Restrictions 
For any movement that takes place following the discovery of a hot axle, a competent person must ride in the vehicle(s) at fault. Duties of the 
competent person during this movement are defined in IMS1640-50. 

Any movement must be at a maximum speed to 10mph over plan line and 5mph over points and crossings. 

Detraining and Removing the Vehicle(s) from Service 
The passengers must be detrained at the Next Station unless the defective vehicle(s) can be detached from the train at that location. If the 
defective vehicle(s) can be detached and securely stabled clear of the running line the remainder of the train may proceed normally.   

If it is not possible to detach and stable the defective vehicle(s) at the Next Station, passengers must be de-trained and the train make the 
shortest possible move to clear the running line. The movement restrictions detailed above still apply.  

Once stabled, all defective vehicles must have a NOT TO GO card affixed to the vehicle detailing the fact that the vehicle has a hot axle. 

Recovery 
Vehicles with confirmed Hot Axles will require a skate move back to a Maintenance Depot. The speed of this move will depend on the speed 
rating of the wheel skate supplied.   Unaffected vehicles may be detached from the defective vehicle(s) at any time and may then proceed 
normally.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

Treating an axle as a Suspect Hot Axle 
An axle must be treated as a suspect hot axle when either: 

a)  The Driver has been unable to examine the train within 10 minutes of a report of the train activating a 

HABD; or  

b)  The train has activated a second HABD for the same axle/side as the first HABD activation, despite there 

being no clear indication of a hot axle; or  

c)  Network Rail have refused to allow the train to remain in service following a series of earlier HABD 

activations which were due to dragging brakes  

Moving a train with a Suspect Hot Axle 
The train must not make any movement without the Controlling Signaller’s authorisation.   

Before any movement can commence, passengers must be removed from the affected vehicle.  A competent 
person must ride in the vehicle(s) at fault. Duties of the competent person during this movement are defined in 
IMS1640-50. 

The train may proceed at a maximum speed of 20mph to clear the line and detrain passengers.  This movement 
must not take the train beyond the First Suitable Station.

On-Train Hot Axle Monitoring 
The Class 387 & Class 80x have a built in hot axle box detection system protecting all wheelsets of the unit.   This system reports the status of 
the unit back to the Driver via the in-cab MITRAC/TMS screen.  

Class 387 (inc Air Fleet) 
If the hot axle box monitoring system becomes defective, MITRAC will report a “HABD Monitoring Unavailable” status to the Driver.  

In the event of a hot-axle box being detected by the on-train system, the in-cab MITRAC screen will alert the Driver with a report of “Axle Bearing 
Failure”.  The Driver will be given the location on the train of the suspect axle bearing. The Driver must bring the train to a stand and examine the 
suspect bearing for any signs of heat.  
If the examination reveals no evidence of overheating, the train can proceed normally. 
If the train is stopped because of a second activation of the same built-in hot axle box detector, or a lineside activation occurs, the train must 
continue at no more that 20mph. 

If the “Axle Bearing Failure” fault cannot be cleared, the train must be treated as if it has a hot axle box regardless of the outcome of the driver’s 
examination. Consequently, the instructions in Table 95 shall apply. 

If the system becomes defective at any time, passengers must be detrained at the First Suitable Station, following which the train may proceed to 
a Maintenance Depot.  

Class 80x 
On Class 80x stock the TMS would provide a Major Event to the driver.  A Tempilstik is available within the emergency equipment cupboard for the driver to check if 
the axle is hot.  

Class 80x - 5-Cars 
If the examination reveals no evidence of overheating, the train can proceed normally. 
If the train is stopped because of a second activation of the same built-in hot axle box detector, or a lineside activation occurs, the train must continue at no more that 
20mph. 

Providing no hot axles are found: If the vehicle’s onboard system needs to be isolated in order to clear the fault, the train can proceed at line speed. Within the next 
50 miles the train must either pass over another Hot Axle Box Detector or the axle(s) in question be re-examined by the Driver or a Rolling Stock Technician. 
The train does not need to be removed from service but must finish at a Maintenance Depot that day. 

Class 80x - 9-Cars 
If the fault is not one of the below vehicles: the vehicle can be treated the same as an 80x 5-Car unit. 

• 
• 

9-car Class 800, coaches 4 & 6 (8240xx/8260xx) 
9-car Class 802, coaches 4 & 6 (8341xx/8361xx) 

If the fault is one of the above vehicles: Due to the vehicle being fitted with a different type of bogie (inboard bearing) these vehicles are not designed to 
activate the lineside HABD equipment, therefore Table 96 must be followed. 

Confirmation of a Hot Axle after examination all 80x traction. 
The instructions in Table 95 shall apply.

On-Train Hot Axle Monitoring 
230001 has on-board Hot Axle Box Detection (HABD), provided by the Wheel Slide Protection (WSP) system.  

In the event of a suspected hot axle box being detected by the on-board system, the Driver will be alerted to this by 
activity on the ‘WSP Activity’ light in the cab. The Driver must bring the train to a stand and examine all axle ends for 
any signs of heat.  

If the examination reveals no evidence of overheating, the train can proceed normally. 

If the train is stopped because of a second activation of the same built-in HABD, or a lineside activation occurs, the 
train must continue at no more that 20mph. 

If the HABD warning via the ‘WSP Activity’ light cannot be cleared, the train must be treated as if it has a hot axle 
box regardless of the outcome of the driver’s examination. Consequently, the instructions in Table 96 shall apply. 

If the system becomes defective at any time, passengers must be detrained at the First Suitable Station, following 
which the train may proceed to a Maintenance Depot.

If a train or vehicle which is in service develops defective hydraulic buffers, the train should proceed in Passenger

INSTRUCTIONS 

Damage occurring In Service 
If a lifeguard on a train or vehicle in service is loose or damaged, it may become a hazard to the infrastructure with the potential to 
cause derailment.  

If the train is to proceed following damage to a lifeguard it must be examined before movement takes place. This examination may 
be conducted by either the Driver or a Rolling Stock Technician.  The purpose of this examination is to establish the level of damage 
to the train and identify any restrictions that shall be applied to onward movement of the train.     

In determining any restrictions that will apply to onward movement of the train (including maximum permissible speed), the Driver, 
Rolling Stock Technician (where provided) and Maintenance Controller shall consider: 

a) 

the circumstances of the incident (including the  likely train speed at the time of impact and the nature of any obstacle 
struck); 
the limitations of any on-site assessment of damage; and 

b) 
c)  whether passengers may be allowed to remain or the train or should be de-trained at or before the First Suitable Station.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

If lighting fails in an individual vehicle(s) within the train: 
Passengers in the  defective  vehicle(s)  shall  normally  be moved to vehicles  with  working  lighting  if  the  train  is  to  pass  through 
tunnels or the journey is within the hours of darkness.  

Where it is not possible to move passengers to other vehicles, a Competent Person shall be stationed in the defective vehicle(s) 
with alternative lighting (hand lamps, light sticks, etc) for as long as the train is traveling through a tunnel or in the hours of darkness.   

If lighting fails along the whole length of the train: 
The train may proceed normally during daylight hours, providing the train is not required to pass through a tunnel.  

The train may not enter service (including passenger service) if the train is required to pass through a tunnel or the journey will not 
be completed by the time darkness falls.  

Should lighting fail whilst the train is in service and the train is either traveling during darkness or will be required to travel through 
a tunnel, passengers must be detrained at the First Suitable Station.  

Note: For Class 15X stock that has been stabled for a length of time, when on-train lighting is inoperable using Compressor 
Speed up can often resolve the fault.  

Emergency Light Sticks 
Trains are allowed to enter service without light sticks, including from a Maintenance Depot.  Where light sticks are missing or have 
been used, they must be replaced as soon as possible. Station fitters at major locations carry stocks of light stick for this purpose.  

Class 175’s  
Controllers are to note that Class 175’s are not supplied with emergency light sticks. Emergency lighting will activate in the event 
of the main lighting failing. 

Class 80x 
Class 80x stock has emergency lighting that will activate in the event of the main lighting failing. 

230001 
Note that 230001 also has emergency lighting that will activate in the event of a failure with the main lighting. The feed to the 
saloon  lights  is  divided  across  three  Miniature  Circuit  Breakers  (MCBs),  one  of  which  supplies  the  emergency  lighting.  These 
emergency lights operate whenever the saloon lights are switched on and will remain illuminated even in the event of an Auxiliary 
Power Supply Unit (APSU) failure, causing load shed, as they can be powered by the auxiliary batteries.

2.  Entering passenger service from a Maintenance Depot and all other locations (all traction)

Greenford – use of an intermediate guard’s door control panel will be necessary but will increase dwell times at

In cab emergency equipment (TW1 section 11)

Passenger emergency equipment

Entering Service

INSTRUCTIONS 
A train with a defective OTDR can only enter service from a Maintenance Depot as long as the defective cab is boxed 
in AND is not to be used. 

A train that has been stabled overnight at a location other than a Maintenance Depot may enter passenger service 
as long as there is another working OTDR on the train. 

A train that develops a defective OTDR en-route in passenger service can remain in service until the end of the day 
as long as there is another working OTDR on the train. 

If ALL OTDR equipment on the train fails: 
The train may complete its journey.  Upon completion of the journey the train may not re-enter service unless the 
unit is to return ECS from an exempt branch line location or another loco or DMU with a working OTDR has been 
attached to the train.

Juridical Recording Unit (JRU) – If the JRU is defective, the Driver will receive a text message on the DMI. If the

above instructions must be followed as appropriate. 

230001

Indicator (OTDRF)’ which is located on the right-hand side of the cab.

If the Pantograph Automatic Dropping Device (ADD) activates the Driver must bring the train to a stand and check 
that the pantograph has dropped, safely stowed and there is no damage to the OLE. 

If there is no obvious damage; 
Class 387 press pan up – if pan raises, or if not and the unit is in multiple, proceed. Refer to Table 7 if one 
pantograph does not raise as load shedding will commence on that unit.  

Class 80x attempt to raise pantograph, proceed on that or other pantograph or engines. Controllers should also 
reference Table 109 if operating in multiple and a non-default pantograph is being used. 

Class 387 – If a single unit and the pan does not raise it is acceptable to isolate the ADD to raise the pan for 
auxiliary supply to supply HVAC and lighting. If the defective unit can be rescued by another 387 re instate the ADD 
on the defective unit before moving. If there is not a rescue unit available the defective unit can proceed with the 
ADD isolated to clear the line at an appropriate speed noting that the pan or carbons could be damaged, which may 
then damage the OLE.  

The pantograph should be properly examined by a Rolling Stock Technician at the earliest available opportunity 
without causing delay or cancellation.  This examination will need to be conducted on a depot away from live 
overhead line equipment and where staff can work safely at height.

•  The vehicle concerned is an end vehicle it is locked out of use; or 
•  A competent person (who could be the Guard) is able to patrol the vehicle concerned and stop 

the train in an emergency.  

If  the  PCA  becomes  defective  in  a  single  vehicle  whilst  in  service  the  train  may  continue  normally 
providing that either: 

•  Passengers can be moved to other vehicles with working PCA; or  
•  The vehicle is an end vehicle which can be locked out of use; or 
•  A competent person (who could be the Guard) is able advise passengers of the location of the 
nearest functional PCA and will regularly patrol the vehicle concerned and stop the train in an 
emergency.  

If the PCA is defective throughout the train: 

The train must be taken out of passenger service at the First Suitable Station and may then run ECS to the Next 
Available Location for repair.   The train may not re-enter Passenger service until the PCA fault is repaired.

If the Call for Aid (CfA) is defective in any vehicle(s):

The Passenger Information System is defined between audio and visual. 

Audible 

A train with a defective audio function on the Passenger Information System can enter service from a Maintenance Depot 
and Passenger Service as long as the PA is working on the train.  The PA functionality on the train must be used as a 
mitigation. If the PA system is defective on the train please refer to Table 116 (Non DOO) and Table 117 (DOO)  

Visual 

A train with less than 50% working visual PIS system on the train is not permitted to enter service from a Maintenance 
Depot. 

A train with 50% or more working visual PIS system working on the train is permitted to enter service from a Maintenance 
Depot. 

Visual PIS failure in a train with 50% or more working 

The train may enter and remain in Passenger Service with the PIS system defective in one or more vehicles as long as 
passengers can be moved to alternative vehicles if required  

If it has not been possible to remove passengers from the affected vehicles arrangements must be put in place for the 
Guard or other Competent Person(s) to regularly patrol the vehicles  - especially on the approach to major stations and 
stations where Selective Door Operation is used. 

Visual PIS failure in a train with less than 50% working. 

The train is not permitted to enter passenger service with a visual PIS failure with less than 50% working on the train in 
DOO operation.  If less than 50% of the visual PIS is working on the train in Non-DOO Operation.  The train can enter 
service as long as a competent person(s) can patrol the vehicles. 

Arrangements must be put in place for the Guard or other Competent Person(s) to regularly patrol the vehicles - especially 
on the approach to major stations and stations where Selective Door Operation is used.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

For 387 traction (inc Air Fleet) attempt a PA reset in accordance with TCMS fault code 5004. 

Partial failure of PA equipment on a train in DOO Passenger Service. 
If a fault develops with PA equipment in a single vehicle whilst in DOO(Passenger) service, passengers shall be removed from the defective vehicle 
at or before the First Suitable Station.  

The train may enter DOO(Passenger) service from other than a Maintenance Depot, but passengers must not be allowed to travel in any vehicles 
with defective PA equipment. 

Total failure of PA equipment throughout the train. 
If  the  Driver  becomes  aware  that  the  PA  system  has  become  completely  defective  whilst  in  DOO(Passenger)  service,  a  workaround  may  be 
available by using the in-cab GSM-R radio handset to initiate a PA broadcast to the train. 

To implement the workaround, the Driver must first check that the PA MCB is not tripped and reset if necessary.  Providing the MCB holds, a PA 
broadcast can then be made via the in-cab GSM-R radio.  To accomplish this, the Driver needs to press the “MU” button on the GSM-R radio 
console, followed by the key combination 5,6,2 on the radio keypad.  The GSM-R system will then over-ride the on-train PA control unit allowing a 
PA message to be broadcast from the GSM-R handset in the cab to the PA system on the train.  

If the workaround is successful: 
Providing the PA can be confirmed as functional using the GSM-R work-around, the train may complete its journeys for the day. The train 
must end the day at a Maintenance Depot capable of affecting a repair.  

If the Workaround is unsuccessful, or the PA MCB will not hold; 
Treat the on-train PA system as completely defective.  The train may not enter DOO Passenger service.  If the failure occurs in-service, 
passengers must be de-trained at the First Suitable Station unless a Guard can be provided to work the train forward.  

If passengers are de-trained, the train may run ECS to a Maintenance Depot for repairs. 

Recovering from a total failure of on-train PA Equipment 
In certain circumstances it may be able to rectify the PA system fault by checking  that all PA handsets are securely fastened in their cradles in 
every cab in the formation.  This check should only be carried out at a location where delay to train services can be avoided.

Entering Service 
The train or traction unit must not enter service from a Maintenance Depot with defective sanding equipment or if 
there is no sand in the sand box.   

The train may enter service from other than a Maintenance Depot if the sanding equipment is defective or there is no 
sand in the sand box except where the Driver believes that there may be difficulty in stopping the train. 

In service 
The train must be taken out of service at the Next Available Location, with passengers de-trained at the First Suitable 
Station if either: 

a)  The driver reports difficulty in stopping; or 
b)  The train is being operated during leaf fall season or during other times of low adhesion where sand may be 

required to assist with train braking. 

If neither of condition a or b above is met, the train can remain in service until the end of the day but must finish at a 
Maintenance Depot. 

Tracking Sander Defects 
The Train Service Manager shall ensure that any vehicle which has been allowed in to service with defective 
sanding equipment is identified with the appropriate restriction within the fleet allocation database.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

A train with defective Selective Door Opening (SDO) equipment may enter service (including from a Maintenance Depot) providing that the SDO 
equipment is not required to be used. This includes Local Door Control being fitted to the Class 16x fleet.  

Where the SDO equipment fails in service on a journey during which SDO operation is required, arrangements must be put in place to either: 

a)  Lock the vehicle(s) out of use to avoid issues at short platforms; or 
b)  Amend the train formation such as to remove the requirement for SDO working; or  
c)  Alter the calling pattern of the train such that SDO operation is not necessary.  
d)  Revert to local door operation on Mkiii automatic door sets 

If none of the above three options are possible, the train should be removed from service at the First Suitable Station; following which the train may 
run as far as the Next Available for repair.  

Class 387 (inc Air Fleet) – Tracklink 3 (PIBS) 
Class 387s are now fitted with an updated SDO system which relies on beacons on the track to tell the unit how many coaches will have their doors 
have released at certain platforms. When the unit fails to detect a beacon where it expects one, the TMS will generate a “missing beacon” alert.  

If the “missing beacon” alert is due to an infrastructure fault; 
The unit can remain in traffic without restriction. 
The location of the missing beacon will need to be placed onto the Late Notice upon advice from N/Rail if this is a second report at that 
location.  

• 
• 

If the “missing beacon” alert is due to a unit fault; 

• 
• 
• 

• 

First or second report for that driving cab; no further action apart from logging the report on R2.  
The train will default to the release pattern of the shortest platform at each station stopped at.  
If there is a 3rd report for that cab; The train can continue to the First Suitable Location where it must terminate. It can then proceed 
ECS to a Maintenance Depot or Next Available Location for repair or remarshalling (boxing in the defective cab is permitted), or remain 
in passenger service if the defective cab is not to be used.  
A cab with a defective SDO system can enter service from a maintenance depot if that cab is not required to be driven from.  

If the system is defective (excluding missed beacon alerts); 

• 

• 

If the SDO system is defective (wrong side door release permitted in error (PIBS fitted station only), more than the permitted doors were 
released for a specific platform for example), then the train should proceed non-stop to the First Suitable Location where the train must 
terminate. It can then proceed ECS to a Maintenance Depot.  
Controllers are to note that a beacon will not work if submerged in water (eg flooding).  

Class 80x 
Class 80x units will now enable correct side door enablement from both balise based ASDO and TMS based ASDO.

enter service (including from a Maintenance Depot) providing that the cab with the defective speedometer can be boxed in or the defective cab is 
not required to be used for all journeys that the train will be required to make.  

The Class 387 Air Fleets speedometer is provided from a feed into the Driver Machine Interface (DMI). If the Driver reports the speedometer as

Entering Service from other than a Maintenance Depot 

A train must not enter passenger service from other than a Maintenance Depot with a defective speedometer in any cab that is required to be used. 

The Class 387 Air Fleets speedometer is provided from a feed into the Driver Machine Interface (DMI). If the Driver reports the speedometer as 
defective, the ETCS on train equipment will also be defective and isolated. 

In Service: 

The Class 387 Air Fleets speedometer is provided from a feed into the Driver Machine Interface (DMI). If the Driver reports the speedometer as 
defective, the ETCS on train equipment will also be defective and isolated.  Therefore, the following instructions will apply. 

Speedometer through the DMI working in conjunction with ERTMS/ETCS is defective.  ETCS will be isolated and this will provide a secondary 
speedometer display from a separate feed through the DMI.  Table 76a  must be followed as the ERTMS/ETCS on train equipment is isolated. 

If the secondary standalone speedometer is also defective.  The Driver will need to operate the train at a speed to ensure all line speeds are 
complied with as well as follow in the instructions in table 76a. 

In all circumstances above, the train must detrain passengers at the next suitable location, following which the train may proceed ECS to the next 
Available Location

A train may enter service from other than a Maintenance Depot providing that at least one tail light is working correctly on  every 
vehicle that is required to be at the front or rear of a train or the train has been provided with a portable tail lamp.  

Partial Failure in Service 
If one tail lamp becomes defective on a train in service which is fitted with two tail lamps, the train can proceed normally.     

Total Failure in Service 
If the provided tail lamp(s) become defective on a train in service resulting in no tail lamp being displayed, and replacement red 
lamp is provided, the train may continue in service until its next scheduled visit to a maintenance depot. 

The portable tail lamp may be a red hand lamp or a purpose made portable tail lamp and there is no speed restriction.  

In the event that it is not possible to provide a replacement red lamp at the rear of the train, the train must not be allowed to remain 
in service beyond the Next Available Location.
