A train with a defective accessible toilet Entering Service from a Maintenance Depot must be communicated to the Customer Experience Manager 
with the planned workings for the day. This is to ensure the information is communicated to the relevant functions and advertised accordingly 

A  train  with  a  defective  accessible  toilet  whilst  in  service,  is  permitted  to  remain  in  service  until  the  end  of  day  but  must  finish  the  day  at  a 
Maintenance Depot.  The Customer Experience Manager must be informed promptly for ensuring IMS-1650-117 is enacted and the information is 
communicated to the relevant functions and advertised accordingly. 

Trains where the accessible toilet is known to be defective should be allocated sensitively, and where possible they should not be allocated to 
diagrams which will work the below.   

• 
• 
• 
• 

High profile services.  
Trains operating long distance, low-frequency routes.  
Late night services.  
Trains serving a major special event.  

Guidance should be sought by the Customer Experience Manager on managing the sensitivity of the allocations. 

Standard Toilets 

A defective standard toilet on board a train is not an out-of-service defect.  If multiple toilets are LOOU of use, Controllers should note that it is a 
requirement to ensure the train has functioning toilets onboard and  IMS-1650-117 should be enacted ensuring the correct communications are 
disseminated. 

Trains where toilets are known to be defective should be allocated sensitively, and where possible they should not be allocated to diagrams which 
will work: 

• 
• 
• 
• 

High profile services.  
Trains operating long distance, low-frequency routes.  
Late night services.  
Trains serving a major special event.  

In  the  event  of  a  number  of  customers  on  board  a  train  with  limited  functioning  toilets  requiring  the  toilet  the  train  may  (at  the  Train  Service 
Managers) undertake a toilet stop at an agreed location.   Toilet stops must not be agreed on lines with an intensive service frequency – passenger 
wishing to use the facilities should continue their journey by other trains.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
Immediately after the Traction Interlock Switch has been isolated and before the train can move all the doors on both sides of the train must be 
checked to ensure that they are securely closed. 

The TIS should only be isolated in the cab from which train is being driven. 

If the TIS has been isolated in service, the train may proceed only as far as the Next Available Location.  In the case of a  passenger train, the 
passengers must be detrained at the First Suitable Station 

On each occasion the doors are operated following isolation of the TIS, the doors on the side of the train where the doors have been opened must 
be checked to ensure they are securely closed before moving. 

At end of the journey, the TIS must be restored to the ‘normal’ position (where possible) before shutting down the Driver’s desk if the train is to be:  
•  Stabled 
•  Reversed 
•  Coupled to another train. 

Class 387 (inc Air Fleet) Notes 
Isolating the TIS on a Class 387 unit also removes two of the three ways which a Driver could be warned about the operation of an Emergency 
Door Egress device within the train.  In the event that an egress device is used, the normal audible in cab warning that the Driver would expect to 
receive will not sound.  Furthermore, the lack of interlock will mean that the interlock light on the cab desk is unlit throughout the journey.   The only 
warning the Driver will get concerning a door emergency egress being activated will be from the MITRAC display unit.  

Class 175 
This function is referred to as the Train Door Interlock Cutout Switch in Table 128a 

Maintenance Controllers are to consult TEAMS instructions regarding door isolations where EBS & TIS are isolated

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

In Service 
Following reports of a traction motor fault, a rotational test must be conducted before any movement can take place.   
Only once it has been established that all wheels on the affected power car or locomotive are turning freely can a 
decision be taken on moving the train.  

The  Maintenance  Controller  and  the  Engineering  on-call  Manager  must  consider  the  likely  nature  of  the  fault  and 
decide whether the train is safe to run.  

Movement must be limited to a maximum speed of 40mph. If the distance to be travelled is greater than 10 miles, 
the train must stop and complete a successful rotational test every 10 miles.  

If at any time the train fails a rotational test, the affected axle must be treated as locked – refer to table 135.  

Reduced Speed Certificate - Code H.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
The MITRAC Intelligent Display Unit (IDU) is the Driver interface to different systems in the train, but the functionality 
of the train is not totally dependent on the IDU functioning.  

Entering Service 
A Class 387 with a defective MITRAC IDU may only enter service from a Maintenance Depot if the defective cab is 
boxed in.  

A Class 387 with a defective MITRAC IDU may only enter service from other than a Maintenance Depot if the defective 
cab is boxed in or the train is running ECS to the Next Available Location to clear the running line.  

In Service Failure 
On Class 387 units if the MITRAC Cab Display Unit has frozen or is greyed out an Aux Off / Aux On of the unit is 
likely to rectify the fault.  

If an Aux off / Aux On of the unit does not rectify the fault, the train may proceed as far as the First Suitable Station 
where passengers must be detrained.  Once passengers have been detrained, the train may proceed to the Next 
Available Location. If after an Aux Off/Aux On the brakes do not release, the MITRAC brake bypass switch may need 
to be operated which should allow the brakes to be released.  

On arrival at the Next Available Location the defective cab must not be used.  Providing the cab can be boxed in, the 
unit may remain in traffic until the end of day when it must finish at a Maintenance Depot.  

If the cab cannot be boxed in, the unit must not enter service unless it is to be driven from a non-defective cab for the 
purposes of travelling to a Maintenance Depot for repair.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

Entering Service 
A Class 80x with a defective TMS may only enter service from a Maintenance Depot if the defective cab is boxed in.  

A Class 80x with a defective TMS may only enter service from other than a Maintenance Depot if the defective cab is 
boxed in or the train is running ECS to the Next Available Location to clear the running line.  

In Service Failure 
The driver should be advised to operate the TMS reset pushbutton located on the back cab wall control panel to re-
boot the active cab TMS. In order to re-boot the TMS the reset pushbutton’s protective cap must be lifted and the 
button pressed. Once operated the system will restart and the active cab TMS monitor will display the loading 
screen.  

If this is unsuccessful the train may proceed as far as the First Suitable Station where passengers must be 
detrained. The driver will not be able to release doors with the TMS defective so egress devices must be 
utilised to de-train passengers. Once passengers have been detrained, the train may proceed to the Next 
Available Location.  

On arrival at the Next Available Location the defective cab must not be used.  Providing the cab can be boxed in, the 
unit may remain in traffic until the end of day when it must finish at a Maintenance Depot.  

If the cab cannot be boxed in, the unit must not enter service unless it is to be driven from a non-defective cab for the 
purposes of travelling to a Maintenance Depot for repair.   

Please note the driver will have to operate the  Pantograph Up (Pan Up) switch in the event of a TMS failure. The 
default pan will be raised (front on a single unit, front and furthest rear on a coupled unit).

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
If it is suspected that one  more wheels may be contaminated; arrangements must be made to examine the train’s 
wheel sets at or before the First Suitable Station. During this examination: 

• 

• 

If a wheel shows a continuous black band of contamination ½-inch (12mm) wide or more in centre of tread, 
treat wheel as contaminated. 
If one or both wheels of an axle are contaminated, treat axle as contaminated   

If more than 50% of the axles are thought to be contaminated;  

the Controlling Signaller must be informed before any further movement commences.  
• 
the train may only proceed in service as far at the Next Available Location.  
• 
•  on arrival at the Next Available location the wheelsets must be examined again.  

Following this second examination if it is established that the wheelsets are no longer contaminated the train may 
continue normally.   If however the wheelsets are still contaminated the train must be immediately removed from 
service.  

Undertaking movement with more than 50% of axles contaminated: 
Any movement of a train with more than 50% of the axles contaminated must be signalled as an ‘On Track 
Machine’.  The service may proceed at line speed, but the Driver should be reminded that the braking distance must 
be increased to compensate for any effects that contamination of the wheels may cause to the braking 
characteristics of the train. 

Note on Examining Wheelsets on trains fitted with Auxiliary Tread Brakes (Class 158) 
Where auxiliary tread brakes (scrubber blocks) are fitted, there may be no evidence of wheel contamination on 
those wheels, so it is important that wheelsets on adjacent vehicles Auxiliary Tread Brakes also examined for 
contamination.

Dragging Brakes 
If dragging brakes on a train cannot be fully released or isolated, the speed of any movement of the train must be restricted as 
follows: 

•  Class 387 – 5pmh at all times.  
•  All other traction – 10mph on plain line, 5mph over points and crossings.   

The passengers must be detrained at the Next Station.  Before further movement may commence, the train must be examined by 
a Rolling Stock Technician.  Following this examination, the Rolling Stock Technician, Maintenance Controller and Duty Service 
Delivery Manager shall establish the degree of further movement that is possible and whether any restrictions need to apply to the 
movement.  

Seized Axles and Shifted Tyres 
Before any movement can take place to clear the line, the train with either a seized axle or shifted tyre must be examined by a 
Rolling Stock Technician.  Following examination it should be decided between the Rolling Stock Technician, Maintenance 
Controller and Duty Service Delivery Manager what degree of movement is possible, whether any restrictions need to apply to the 
movement and the location at which the passengers will be de-trained.  
On trains formed of Diesel Multiple Unit stock, it may be necessary to remove the cardan shafts from one or more transmissions 
before movement can commence.   

Recovery of a train with Seized Axles or Shifted Tyres 
Vehicles with confirmed seized axle which cannot be rectified in situ will require a skate move back to a Maintenance Depot. 
The speed of this move will depend on the speed rating of the wheel skate supplied.   Unaffected vehicles may be detached 
form the defective vehicle(s) at any time and may then proceed normally.  

Examining the Line 
If a train has moved with either a locked axle or shifted tyres Network Rail must be reminded to arrange for the line to be 
examined.  

Traction types with Tyres 
Note that other than Class 08 shunting locomotives all GWR traction has monoblock wheelsets which do not have tyres by design.  

Class 80x 
Driver/ Duty Service Delivery Manager to liaise with Hitachi technical staff prior to movement.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

Entering Service 
A train with defective Wheel Slide Protection (WSP) must not enter service from a Maintenance Depot.  

A train which has been stabled overnight at a location other than a Maintenance Depot may not enter passenger service at the 
start of a day’s diagram.  The train must only be allowed to make one ECS move directly to a Maintenance Depot and only if the 
Driver does not believe that there will be issues with stopping the train.   

A train which has become defective during a day’s diagram may re-enter passenger service during the same day providing that: 

• 
• 
• 

The train will end at a Maintenance Depot at the end of the day; and 
The Driver does not believe that there will be any difficulty in stopping; and 
The train is not operating during the leaf fall season or at other times where low adhesion is likely. 

In service 
The train must be taken out of service at the Next Available Location, with passengers de-trained at the First Suitable Station if 
either: 

a)  The driver reports difficulty in stopping; or 
b)  The train is being operated during leaf fall season or during other times of low adhesion where WSP may be required to 

assist with train braking. 

If neither condition a or b applies, the train can remain in service until the end of the day but must finish at a Maintenance Depot. 

If the WSP equipment has failed it is likely that the speedometer will revert to zero in the defective cab. Should the speedometer 
be defective, refer to Table 123 – Speedometer – Defective or Inaccurate.  
.

In service 
If  a  Panel  Available  light  on  a  Guards  Operating  Panel  (GOP)  remains  illuminated  when  moving  then  it  must  be  immediately  reported  to  the 
Maintenance Controller’, the train must be removed from service (at the First Suitable Station). The vehicle must be evacuated, and a competent 
person must patrol the vehicle and doors.  The train must proceed ECS to a Maintenance Depot for repairs 

The risk is as follows:  The power on light remaining when moving is an indication that there is a loss of speed input signals to the Door Control 
Unit (DCU), in this situation, if an Emergency Egress Device (EED) is operated – the external door will open irrespective of train speed or even if 
the door has previously been locked out of use. 

Conducting a Rotational Test – All traction in this table. 
In the event that the WSP fault light remains illuminated both under braking  and whilst the Driver is taking power  or coasting the train must be 
stopped and a rotational test completed before allowing the train to proceed.  This is  in order to mitigate against a potential failure in the locked 
axle detection system on the train.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

A window with a crack of more than 80mm (approximately 3 inches) must be considered as broken.  

Entering Service 
A train / traction unit with a broken or obscured windscreen can enter service (including from a Maintenance Depot) 
providing that the defective cab is not required to  be  used (for example boxed in or will be trailing for all required 
journeys).  

Whilst in Service 
Should the windscreen be broken, or the Driver considers their view of the line ahead is obscured, the judgement of 
the Driver must be used as the basis of the decision as to whether the train can continue to be driven from the 
defective cab.  

If the train is to proceed whilst being driven from the defective cab, consideration shall be given to implementing 
additional mitigation steps to ensure that the train and anybody on or near the line is not placed in danger.  These 
mitigating steps may include: 

Increased used of the train horn.  

• 
•  Running at a reduced speed (as agreed with the Driver based on their opinion of the level of visibility 

afforded by the broken or obscured windscreen).  

•  Provision of a Competent Person. 
•  Turning the train or boxing in the defective cab.  
•  Consideration of the Driver’s judgement as to whether the train is safe to remain in service.  In the event 

that the Driver considers the train unsafe to remain in service arrangements will need to be put in place to 
terminate the train at or before the Next Available Location.

A unit may only enter service from a Maintenance Depot with a visually fault-free Fast Charge shoegear 
system; this is checked as part of the Train Prep.  

If the shoegear or any other component of the Fast Charging system develops a fault during service, this will 
manifest itself as one or more failed Fast Charges, indicated to the driver by the fact that the Fast Charge 
Indicator Light (FCIL) will not illuminate. In such scenarios, the Driver should contact Maintenance Control 
who will use the procedures set out in FCBTT-00044 to determine whether the train can continue in service, 
or should return to the nearest Maintenance Depot for inspection or repair. 

If the Driver reports visual damage to the shoegear, then the train must be taken out of service at the Next 
Available Location, with passengers de-trained at the First Suitable Station, then the train should be returned 
to the Maintenance Depot. 

For information: 
Under normal conditions, the Fast Charge shoegear is pneumatically operated and defaults to the “up” 
position, i.e. stowed well within gauge.  

The shoegear pneumatic system is controlled by electrically-operated solenoid valves, and these also default 
to “up” (i.e. stowed). If the electrical control voltage is lost, the solenoids ensure that the shoes are driven 
back up. If both the pneumatic and the electrical supply fails, the shoes are retracted by backup mechanical 
springs. 

The system needs air pressure to operate properly, because the shoes are pushed down on to the rails with 
a pneumatic piston, needed to ensure sufficient electrical contact between the shoes and charge rails. The 
air pressure is monitored and if it falls below a certain threshold then the charging will not start, or will 
terminate, and the shoes will retract.  

It will normally be safe to drive back to the Maintenance Depot with defective shoegear, providing the 
shoegear is not ‘stuck down’ or otherwise presenting a risk of damage to the infrastructure. However, due to 
the backup springs mentioned earlier, having the shoegear stuck down is very unlikely.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
A fault with one or more traction batteries will manifest itself via the relevant Power Pack Fault light being illuminated 
in the cab, on the Fault Indication Panel (FIP), as well as the General Fault light being illuminated (There are three 
Power Pack Fault lights in each cab, one for each of the three traction batteries on a DM car). 

Note that a simple trip/reset of the train can often fix the issue if a Power Pack Fault light comes up on the FIP (and 
often in other cases too).The train will take a little while to boot up so wait approximately 5 to 7 minutes after boot up 
for any Power Pack Fault lights to clear. 

If the Power Pack Fault light continues to be illuminated after a simple trip/reset of the train, the Driver should contact 
Maintenance Control who will use the procedures set out in FCBTT-00044 to determine whether the train can continue 
in service, or should return to the nearest Maintenance Depot for inspection or repair.

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 
The TCU, one on each DM car, supplies that vehicle’s traction motors and APSU, it also facilitates Fast Charging of 
the traction batteries.  

If a TCU is defective then tractive effort, saloon heating and auxiliary power will be lost on that vehicle, but control 
systems, cab heating and cab aircon will remain functional using power from the other DM car’s APSU.  

A defective TCU will also mean that the traction batteries on the affected vehicle cannot be charged, either via the 
Fast Charge system or via shore supply in the Depot.  

If a DM has a working TCU but failed APSU, the following functionality will be lost in the affected car: 

•  3 of the 6 saloon cooling units 
•  Saloon and cab 230V AC power and USB sockets. 
•  Cleaner’s 230V AC power socket. 

Although the compressor local to the failed APSU will not operate, the air system will be fed pneumatically by the 
compressor on the unaffected DM car. 

The train may complete its journey with a failed TCU, but since it will have an effect on traction battery charging, the 
Driver should contact Maintenance Control at the first available opportunity, who will use the procedures set out in

From a Maintenance Depot

sections.In Service:
INSTRUCTIONS 

Firstly check to see whether the Compressor Control Circuit Breaker (CCCB) has tripped. The CCCB can be found 
on the cab back wall (one in each cab). 

If this doesn’t solve the problem, go to the ‘SCTC’ saloon end cupboard which is adjacent to the gangway, open the 
panel and check to see whether the main Compressor Circuit Breaker (CCB) has tripped (one in each DM car). 

If either the CCCB or the CCB has tripped, reinstate them and wait to see whether the air builds up again. If the air 
builds up but then any of the circuit breakers trip again, or this is not the root cause of the air loss, the unit should be 
withdrawn from service and returned to the nearest Maintenance Depot for inspection or repair at the earliest 
opportunity. The unit is not to leave the Maintenance Depot with a faulty / tripped air compressor / without the 
correct MR pressure being maintained (between 8 and 9.5 bar). 

If the train needs to be rescued / recovered, use procedure FCBTT-00005 230001 Breakdown and Recovery 
Manual.
